text:
This new store, specializing in traditional handmade noodles, has quickly become a new favorite of mine.   The noodles themselves are a true delight, with a perfect balance of chewiness and tenderness.  Whether you opt for the classic broth-based dish or the flavorful dry variation, the depth of flavors is simply remarkable.

The Hakka ÈªÑÈÖíÂπºÈù¢ is a delightful bowl of comfort that warms both the soul and the stomach!  The rich aroma of yellow wine filled my senses, adding a lovely depth to the broth.  Each strand of noodles carried the essence of the soup, making every slurp a joy.  The balance of sweet, savory, and umami notes kept me coming back for more ‚Äî before I knew it, the bowl was empty!

Chilli Mee Hoon Kueh $5.90

Brought my dog out for a walk, so had to eat in the dark üòÖ (Coffee shop does not allow pets üê∂üö´)

I quite enjoy this bowl of Mee Hoon Kueh üçú with the chili paste üî• and the dark sauce. Good amount of minced meat and veggies as well.

New stall. Black soya sauce taste good. Quantity is small.

The only difference between the chilli ban mian and the dry ban mian is the type of chilli used. Personally I won‚Äôt pay for the $.90 difference. The dry ban mian taste juts as good.

Stall is located in kimly coffee shop.

Nice ban mian stall. Always eat the traditional dry and the chicken cutlet items. I like that the noodle portion isn‚Äôt just large. It‚Äôs a balanced serving w egg, anchovies, veg and sauce. The sauce is some mix of soy sauce, vinegar and oil (reminds me of Chinese cooking) and the chilli is power. For chicken cutlet, the chicken is crispy but no chilli. If want chilli top up $1.
Surprised the dry ban mee tastes good
